graphicslib3D

Class Material

  • java.lang.Object
    • graphicslib3D.Material
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    java.io.Serializable, java.lang.Cloneable

    public class Material
extends java.lang.Object
implements java.lang.Cloneable, java.io.Serializable
    This class encapsulates the material parameters of Materials in OpenGL. Materials contain R,G,B, and A coefficient values for each of Ambient, Diffuse, and Specular reflection, and also have a "shininess" value. Materials also have RGBA values for Emission. Reflection and emission coefficients are float values in the range 0 to 1 (inclusive); glossiness is a float value in the range 0 to 128 (inclusive).

    For convenience, several static final materials are defined in the class.

    Author:
    Yun Liang, John Clevenger, based on an earlier version by, Monika Jankun-Kelly., Scott Gordon removed openGL-specific Material references.
    See Also:
    Serialized Form

      Fields 
      Modifier and Type Field and Description
      static Material BRONZE
      A predefined material with the ambient, diffuse, specular, and shininess characteristics of Bronze.
      static Material GOLD
      A predefined material with the ambient, diffuse, specular, and shininess characteristics of Gold.
      static Material SILVER
      A predefined material with the ambient, diffuse, specular, and shininess characteristics of Silver.

      Constructors 
      Constructor and Description
      Material()
      Creates a default material with a unique default name and default color values.

      Creates a material with the specified name and the default values.
      Material(java.lang.String name, float[] ambient, float[] diffuse, float[] specular, float[] emission, float shininess)
      Creates a material with the specified name and the specified reflection, emission, and shininess values.

      • Material

        public Material()
        Creates a default material with a unique default name and default color values. The default color values match the defaults defined by OpenGL (see glMaterial()).

    • Method Detail

      • clone

        public java.lang.Object clone()
        Returns a new material object which is a clone of this material. The returned material has reflection, emission, and glossiness values which are duplicates of this material's values.
        Overrides:
        clone in class java.lang.Object

      • setName

        public void setName(java.lang.String n)
        Sets a new name for this material.

      • setAmbient

        public void setAmbient(float[] vals)
        Sets the ambient reflection coefficients of this material. If the input array is not of size 4 then an UnsupportedOperation exception is thrown. If any of the four values in the input array is outside the allowable range of 0<=val<=1 then the corresponding value is clamped to the limit of the range in that direction (but no error notice is given).

      • setDiffuse

        public void setDiffuse(float[] vals)
        Sets the diffuse reflection coefficients of this material. If the input array is not of size 4 then an UnsupportedOperation exception is thrown. If any of the four values in the input array is outside the allowable range of 0<=val<=1 then the corresponding value is clamped to the limit of the range in that direction (but no error notice is given).

      • setSpecular

        public void setSpecular(float[] vals)
        Sets the specular reflection coefficients of this material. If the input array is not of size 4 then an UnsupportedOperation exception is thrown. If any of the four values in the input array is outside the allowable range of 0<=val<=1 then the corresponding value is clamped to the limit of the range in that direction (but no error notice is given).

      • setEmission

        public void setEmission(float[] vals)
        Sets the emission coefficients of this material. If the input array is not of size 4 then an UnsupportedOperation exception is thrown. If any of the four values in the input array is outside the allowable range of 0<=val<=1 then the corresponding value is clamped to the limit of the range in that direction (but no error notice is given).

      • setShininess

        public void setShininess(float newShininess)
        Sets the glossiness value of the material. The value must be in the range 0 to 128; otherwise the value is silently ignored and the material remains unchanged.

      • toString

        public java.lang.String toString()
        Returns a printable representation of this Material.
        Overrides:
        toString in class java.lang.Object
